Award.AwardTitle: Constraining the Secular Compositional Evolution of the Upper Continental Crust Using Ancient Glacial Deposits and Creation of an Upper Crustal Reference Suite
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Earth is unique amongst the planets of our Solar System in having a crust of silica-rich, low-density rock that forms our continents. It is upon this platform that our species evolved and it provides the essential resources needed to maintain our society. Understanding the processes by which the continental crust formed is one of the grand questions in geology. A clue to the origin of continental crust is its average composition. The crust's composition also factors prominently in determining the amount of heat producing elements that remained in the Earth's mantle after formation of the crust; these elements provide the energy needed to drive plate tectonics. Within the continental crust, most of the heat-producing elements are concentrated in the upper 10 km. Hence, determining the composition of the upper crust, and associated uncertainties, is crucial in understanding continental crust formation and evolution, as well as the energy balance of the Earth's interior.

This project seeks insights into the composition of the upper continental crust through analysis of glacial sedimentary deposits from around the world. These deposits date from 2.9 to 0.3 Ga and provide insight into how the average composition of the Earth's upper crust has changed with time. The changing composition can, in turn, be used to infer the processes that formed the crust, as well as the changing conditions prevalent at the Earth's surface. The fine-grained matrix of the tillites will be analyzed for a comprehensive suite of major and trace elements and isotopic compositions. The effects of weathering and of changes in atmospheric composition on crustal composition will be assessed. These samples will form the basis of an upper crustal reference suite that will be made available to the community for further characterization of the upper continental crust through time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Determining the composition of the continental crust, the birthplace and habitat of homo sapiens, is important for understanding the processes by which continents form and evolve over time. Using such data we can address questions such as a) Were the processes of continent formation the same in the past as they are today?, and b) how has the Earth’s surface environment changed from the Archean to the present? We have taken a novel approach to investigating how the composition of the uppermost continental crust has changed over time by analyzing the fine-grained portions of ancient glacial tillites, ranging in age from 2.9 billion years to 300 million years. Glaciers scrape off and pulverize the surface over which they move, and these deposits provide a grand average of the crust that the glaciers traversed. Because the process of creating tillites is physical – scouring, plucking and pulverizing rock, compositional effects associated with chemical weathering during the formation of these deposits are expected to be minimal.

The chemistry of the tillites shows that the upper continental crust (UCC) of the Archean Earth (before 2.5 billion years) was fundamentally different from younger UCC. The Archean crust had large proportions of mafic and ultramafic rocks, as reflected in high abundances of transition metals (Cr, Co, Ni, see Fig. 1) and platinum group elements (PGEs: Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir, Pt, see Fig. 2). These features suggest that crustal formation during the first half of Earth history was fundamentally different from that in the second half of Earth history. Another first-order feature of the tillite compositions is a strong, nearly ubiquitous chemical weathering signature (high Al relative to Ca, Na, K; strong depletion in soluble elements such as Sr) that reflects the weathered nature of the crust over which the glaciers moved. The weathering signature is greatest in the Archean and has decreased since then, implying that weathering intensity was greater in the early Earth. Moreover, the tillites record the rise of atmospheric oxygen, as certain elements whose solubility varies depending on their oxidation state (e.g., Mo, V, which are soluble in their most oxidized 6+ states) are systematically depleted in tilites deposited after the great oxidation event (GOE), when atmospheric oxygen rose above 20 parts per million (see Figures 1 and 3). Most interestingly, one deposit that formed prior to the GOE (as defined on the basis of the presence of mass independent fractionation – MIF -- of sulfur isotopes), the Duitschland Formation in South Africa, shows evidence of strong oxidative weathering, suggesting either that significant oxygen may have risen in the atmosphere prior to the GOE, or, more likely, that the MIF signature is smeared out by sedimentary recycling and cannibalization. 

 This work has resulted in the training of one early career scientist (post-doc Richard Gaschnig) and in several PhD students who visited for a period of one to two years from China (Su Li, China Petroleum University) and Kang Chen (China University of Geosciences, Wuhan). We also employed several undergraduate research assistants, Will Junkin, Michael Ream, Claire Zurkowski, who were trained in sample preparation and geochemical analyses.

Finally, we have created an upper crustal reference suite of 24 composite samples (comprising over 100 individual samples) of each of the formations we studied. We have made these composites available to the community for further characterization of the upper continental crust through time. To date, the following investigators are working on these samples: James Farquhar (Univ. Maryland) for sulfur isotopes, Fang Huang (Univ. Sci. and Technology of China) for V and Ba isotopes, Chris Reinhard (Georgia Tech) and Noah Planavsky (Yale) for Cr and U isotopes.
